sentence: The editors said that the S&P would hit 2200 in Thanksgiving week…and they were right!
The index climbed only 0.22%, but that was enough to finish at another new high of 2202.9.
Perhaps Jeremy put it best in Zacks Counterstrike : "The long awaited 2200 print in the S&P finally came.
We can now stop talking about it and start looking at what might come next."
But that wasn't all.
The Dow also recorded a new high and crossed its own psychological barrier of 19,000.
It climbed 0.35% to 19023.9.
And the NASDAQ wasn't left out of the party.
It gained 0.33% to a new record of 5386.4.
If you're keeping score, that's a second straight day of all three major indices making history.
So now what?
Jeremy sees 2240 as an easy goal for the S&P by the end of the year.
In Reitmeister Trading Alert , Steve was talking about a "melt up", which is something in between a consolidation and a breakout.
There was no early holiday for the portfolios on Tuesday, as activity spiked after a couple quiet sessions.
Three portfolios banked double digit gains, led by a more than 50% return for Home Run Investor .
Five portfolios bought, including the latest two additions from Large-Cap Trader .
Let's just get right to all the action.
→ When Four Corners Property Trust (FCPT) came up to bat for Home Run Investor last year, Dave didn't have much faith in this spinoff from his previous Darden Restaurants position.
But the REIT just kept moving higher, so the editor left it in the lineup.
Now shares are struggling a bit and it looks to be time to get out, but FCPT brought a nice 55% return to the portfolio.
Dave calls it a ground-rule double…not bad for a player that was almost benched.
By the way, he also added today (see below).
→ The Zacks Short List had only two sells in this week's adjustment…and one of them was a double-digit gainer.
The portfolio short-covered Agnico Eagle (AEM) on Tuesday, bringing a profit of 17.4% in just a little over three weeks.
Read about the portfolio's other moves below.
→ With Tilly's (TLYS) scheduled to report its fiscal third quarter on November 30, Jeremy thought this would be a good time to get out of the retailer.
Analyst numbers are fine and estimates have stayed flat, but we all know how unpredictable an earnings report can be.
The stock could very well give up its entire gain if it misses.
Therefore, the editor sold TLYS from Zacks Counterstrike and banked a 14.4% profit.
• The Iron Mining Industry is hot right now with a Zacks Industry Rank in the top 5%(!
)…and John found a company from this space that's still cheap and has potential to double or triple in price moving forward.
Vale SA (VALE) is a Brazilian mining company that's a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy).
It is one of the newest additions to Large-Cap Trader .
The editor plans to capitalize on price momentum as this company is in turnaround mode.
He is most attracted to its PEG Ratio of 0.46, suggesting that there's plenty of running room for the future.
It also has a Zacks VGM Score of "A" and reported a positive EPS surprise of 36% in its most recent report.
But you already know that the new Large-Cap Trader is filling up its portfolio two at a time.
The other buy on Tuesday was Sabre (SABR), a provider of technology solutions to the thriving global travel and tourism industry.
As part of the Internet-Software space, SABR also has an impressive Zacks Industry Rank in the top 19%.
This Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) has a Zacks VGM Score of B, and has beaten the Zacks Consensus Estimate by an average of 9.7% in the last four quarters.
The most recent beat was 21%.
The "prized fundamental" for John is a net profit margin of 10.52%, which is above the S&P average of 10.1%.
As with the portfolio's other picks, each of these new additions have an 8% allocation.
Read the complete commentary for a lot more on both.
• The financials have been a big beneficiary of the "Trump rotation" with a Zacks Industry Rank in the top 14%, so that's where Dave went for the newest addition to Home Run Investor.
PennyMac Financial (PFSI) is a financial services provider that does mortgage banking and investment management.
The editor says "it's all about revenue growth here" , as it is expected to jump 25% this quarter and nearly 43% next.
Dave thinks this could lead to multiple expansion.
He sees a very good six to twelve months for PFSI as long as it continues to beat estimates.
Read the full write-up for more.
• If you want to see a truly dramatic turnaround for a company, then look no further than Oclaro (OCLR).
This provider of optical components for telecom used to miss earnings quarter after quarter…but that all changed in early 2015.
Now, the company has an average earnings surprise of 100% over the last four quarters.
Earnings estimates are up 34% for the rest of this year and 26% for next year…and let's not forget that it's part of a hot space in the top 15% of the Zacks Industry Rank.
This approximately $9.6 stock has a long way to run to get to its target price of $12.19, and Steve plans to profit all the way there with a 6.8% allocation in OCLR for Reitmeister Trading Alert .
Read the full writeup for more.
• Ultra Clean Holdings (UCTT) is "red hot" right now, according to Dave.
In fact, the company is "nearly too hot" right now, but the editor isn't afraid of getting burned and plans to play the breakout from $10 in Momentum Trader .
He took a 12.5% allocation in UCTT on Tuesday.
The company is a developer and supplier of critical subsystems for the semiconductor capital equipment, flat panel, solar and medical device industry.
By the way, the portfolio also got out of FANG today for a 4.8% return.
Read the complete commentary for more.
• In addition to AEM (mentioned above), the Zacks Short List also short-covered WMB on Tuesday.
The two new picks that replaced these names are Salesforce.com (CRM) and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD).
Learn more about this emotion-free portfolio that takes advantage of falling and volatile markets by reading the Short List Trader Guide.
